title: Response to West et al. (2023)
text:
Letter
Avoided Deforestation Conservation Projects (ADCP) must deliver carbon emission reductions and necessitate comparisons between observations in protected forests and counterfactual scenarios. West et al.1 used the synthetic control (SC) method to choose pools of controls with similar covariate structure to ADCP. The SC is calculated from the mean deforestation rate of pools, weighted by covariate similarity with the project. We agree SC could improve the evaluation of ADCP. However, SC are also vulnerable to “gaming” or bias through inappropriate donor pool design/sampling and require further refinement before they can improve upon existing ADCP approaches.
West et al.1 claim that most ADCP overestimate avoided deforestation or do not significantly reduce deforestation. These claims are misleading or inaccurate for these reasons:
The current implementation of SC can suffer from bias2 due to substantial and incompatible differences between deforestation drivers, forest structure and geography that are not captured. Important covariates are ignored, such as: distance to roads3, or indicators of forest structure that predict timber value and logging effort. Using the authors’ code, we extracted the locations of controls used to create the SC for project-856 (Figure 1), located in Pacific montane-forest. No donors were located in the same state or ecoregion and the highest weighted donor (0.46) was 900 km away in the Amazon.
Calculations derived from Global Forest Change (GFC) data4 inherit known sensitivity and accuracy issues5,6. It is inappropriate to compare GFC-based calculations with those reported by projects, that should be better calibrated for local contexts, because meaningful comparisons require deforestation rates be derived using the same approach. Further, it is accepted that GFC is inappropriate for site-level deforestation assessment, in isolation6,7.
SC counterfactuals were never demonstrated to be more accurate than methods reported by projects, which confounds the ability to interpret differences between the SC and project-reported deforestation rates.



Figure 1: Map of the donor pool and their weighted contribution to the Synthetic Control for the Colombian Project 856, overlaying a map of Colombian ecoregions8 that intersect the weighted donors. Project-856was selected because it is the only one that the authors provide fully reproducible code for. To see interactive maps of this and all other projects please see … Elevation data from https://registry.opendata.aws/terrain-tiles.
